phrase: Galaxies are collections of gas, dust, and billions of stars and their solar systems, held together by gravity.
author: spaceplace.nasa.gov

phrase: All the planets in our solar system orbit the Sun. Planets that orbit other stars are called exoplanets.
author: spaceplace.nasa.gov

phrase: A nebula is a giant cloud of dust and gas in space. Some nebulae come from gas and dust ejected by the explosion of a dying star, such as a supernova.
author: spaceplace.nasa.gov

phrase: The Sun is 400 times bigger than the Moon, but it is also 400 times farther away, making both objects appear to be the same size in our sky.
author: oaq.epn.edu.ec

phrase: The observable Universe is 93 billion light years in size. This means that, taking into account that light travels at a speed of 300,000 kilometers per second, it would take us all this time to cross it.
author: oaq.epn.edu.ec

phrase: Scientists can detect the gravitational influence of dark matter, but have not seen it, despite the fact that it makes up 85% of the matter in the universe and 26.8% of its energy density.
author: oaq.epn.edu.ec

phrase: There are many asteroids in our solar system. Most live in the main asteroid belt, a region between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter.
author: spaceplace.nasa.gov

phrase: The Andromeda Galaxy (M31) contains more than 300 billion stars, and the total mass of the galaxy may exceed a trillion suns.
author: oaq.epn.edu.ec

phrase: One millionth of a millionth of a millionth of a millionth of a millionth of a second after the Big Bang, the universe was the size of a pea.
author: academiaplay.es

phrase: When you look at the sky, what you see is really what was happening in the past. Since light takes time to reach us, the image we see is the one projected by the cosmos long ago.
author: esquire.com

phrase: Neutron stars are the fastest spinning objects in the entire cosmos. Among them, some especially fast ones, called pulsars, would be the most terrifying fairground attraction you can imagine.
author: esquire.com
